title: 110_hr3424
content: Authorization of appropriations for tax law enforcement related to human sex trafficking. Authorization of $4,000,000 for fiscal year 2008 to establish an office within the IRS to investigate and prosecute violations of internal revenue laws related to human sex trafficking. Amounts appropriated will remain available for fiscal year 2009. In 2009, additional funding was authorized for the operations of an office established to administer tax collections and penalties under the Internal Revenue Code. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to report on the enforcement activities of this office to specific congressional committees within one year of the enactment of the Act. The office established under subsection (a)(1) must provide recommendations for statutory changes to aid in future prosecutions. Whistleblower awards under the Internal Revenue Code can be given to victims of human sex trafficking without considering certain criteria. SEC. 2. Increase in criminal monetary penalty limitation for tax fraud. Increase in criminal monetary penalty limitation for tax fraud under Section 7201 and willful failure to file return under Section 7203 amended to raise penalties to $500,000 ($1,000,000) and 10 years respectively. The amendment increases penalties for tax fraud and failure to file returns to $500,000 ($1,000,000) and 10 years, respectively. It also introduces a new subsection for aggravated failure to file. The amendment introduces increased penalties for tax fraud and failure to file returns, including a penalty for aggregated failure to file if tax liability exceeds $100,000 for 3 consecutive years. Additionally, penalties under sections 6674 and 7203 may be applied in cases of fraudulent statements or failure to make statements to employees. The amendment increases penalties for tax fraud and failure to file returns, including raising the monetary limit to $500,000 ($1,000,000) and increasing the imprisonment term to 5 years. If any underpayment or overpayment of tax is due to fraudulent action, the applicable dollar limit is increased. The amendment increases penalties for tax fraud and failure to file returns, including raising the monetary limit to $500,000 ($1,000,000) and increasing the imprisonment term to 5 years. The applicable dollar amount for fraudulent actions shall not be less than a certain portion, with rules similar to section 6663(b) applying. These amendments apply to actions occurring after the enactment of this Act.
